WRITING.TEXT:
Thank you! I've been giving those little brushes a workout. The book I got is a Stillman Birn Beta series. All I've been using to paint on was the cheapest of cheap paper from Hobby Lobby and I was dying to try something a little better after getting more confident and recognizing the shortcomings of the cheap pads.
As I've laid out, I'm not really familiar with a lot of paper but I find it really terrific. It's cold-press but the texture is much less pronounced than the other paper I've tried so it doesn't get in the way of the tiny details on these tiny foods. I do a fair amount of scrubbing and lifting and I have yet to start tearing up spots and pulling up fuzzy bits of paper. It works like a champ. I'm curious to try out some books, but I'm glad to have found a good quality journal I can pick up locally.

Thanks very much. That's a personal challenge for me with all these. I enjoy painting realistically and sometimes that can kinda be at odds with choosing watercolor! But I decided I wanted to tackled these with as much effort and eye for detail as I would something on letter size paper. It's more fun and satisfying for me, and in the long run it'll be good training for approaching details on larger paintings. The values are something else I'm very conscious of. Just like watercolor can sometimes fight you on adding detail, it can be defy strong contrasts and deep values so I'm always trying to push that and go a step or two further with some dark, pigment loaded strokes.
The notebook has 52 pages, so once it's filled, there should be almost enough for a little meal.

I bought a new pocket sketchbook and decided to make it a dedicated tiny food book. I don't always have the most consistent, wide open chunks of time to paint, so sticking with a tiny portrait of a single object has made it much easier to complete a painting in a single sitting or two and get that sweet, sweet sense of accomplishment.

WRITING.TITLE: A week's worth of tiny food

WRITING.TEXT: I think the factory paint is chipping, hence wondering if there are known exact values to match.
The showrunner hates a wig and they don't change it?

A game is a game, the fun is being in control of the story and feel like you're the protagonist. A game isn't a movie, but with stuff like this it doesn't feel much different than putting a movie up on YouTube. And we all know the studios would shit their pants at the idea of their new movie showing up on YouTube the Friday it opened. The same is said for movie/TV pirates, that they were never going to be a paying customer anyway, so what's the harm if movies do show up online for free.
I don't really have a concrete point, other than I'm just surprised how cavalier game studios are compared to Hollywood.

I can definitely appreciate that. I've got such a backlog of games and other things to grab my attention I've hardly ever played a game twice but I do get curious about how different paths might have unfolded.

I watch lots of gaming videos, but I'm realizing now when I actually think about it, I only watch "engine" type games like Civilization or Crusader Kings or Cities Skylines. I've never sought out any narrative games and saw how commonplace it was.
I guess it's true that I have no intention of buying the game and so I'm fine with watching. Where as if it was a game like this I was interested in, I definitely wouldn't watch and have the story spoiled for me. Seems kinda like a catch-22(or some figure of speech I can't quite come up with), companies allow it because it's free publicity but the people watching are people who were never going to buy. So...that doesn't quite add up.

Huh, I thought it would be...I dunno, a more shadier, sneakier outlet to see them, or they'd be modified and uploaded in some weird way to avoid getting taken down. Not uploaded plainly and proudly by IGN. Is this normal now? Companies cool with their story being thrown up online for free on the release date?

I'll be very curious to see how they approach the return. I think your idea is for the best, just wave everything post Dan's heart attack away. They haven't been afraid to break the fourth wall and be meta-y sometimes, like acknowledging the actress swap for Becky.

Perhaps an easier way to fix things, at least according to me..the armchair expert TV writer, would've been to limit her rewriting to that last year or so. Not swap David and Mark, or make her mom gay and undo portions of the entire series. Her coping with Dan's death is like a gut-punch and wonderful, but everything tampered with prior to that feels thrown in unnecessarily.
I forgot to mention Roseanne wanting to be a writer early on. With that idea existing from the very beginning, and her just attempting to "fix" that last season...I think it would've been more appreciated
You've got a continent on either side to build up speed, just need a ramp.
The image of KenM carefully, quietly placing the testicles, and just the testicles, into a bowl never fails to crack me up.
What was the title? Just a couple weeks ago I was randomly wondering if there were some good documentaries about Waco.
Gene: Buy a vowel!
For sure, I'm grasping at straws with Mark. Which makes even the mild statement "some actors have died" completely wrong.
Oh no! Not posts from one of the best sitcoms made!

It probably wouldn't be as polarizing if...say, 85% of the show wasn't grounded and depressing. Until the lottery, the show was never hinted to be anything but a realistic look at a wiring class family. The ending was certainly something just thought up in the last season. It would've benefited from more outlandish or fanciful ideas being introduced or amplified steadily as the show progressed. Like Roseanne wanted to write an honest memoir, but realized it was too bleak and needed some spicing up along the way. That would've made the finale more acceptable and more satisfying. As it stands, all it does is make the shittiest season almost palatable, drop in maybe one good, emotional ret con and then erase or make you question a lot of what you enjoyed about the story. I feel very moved by the finale, but it also feels like cheap, unearned manipulation.
The only element, off the top of my head..it's been a few years since I've seen a lot of the show, I could maybe accept as fitting my suggestion and feeling fictional during the run of the show would be the Halloween episodes, where any money or time concerns seem to be entirely forgotten. But that's more likely attributed to Roseanne probably just being a big fan of Halloween and wanting to have fun with those episodes, and not towards any grand plan with the show's overall narrative.
Yeah the only quasi-main character needing written out would be Mark, played by Glenn Quinn.
Simmer down, Carol Pilbasian.
I'd love to see that too, very satisfying reworking of the myth.
Oh cool, I'd like to see it, link?
She sounds ghoulish.
I think it's more of a thematic connection.

As sad or silly as it might sound to "outsiders", the Steam sales used to feel like a holiday to me. I was excited to check out the flash sales at over rotation. The feeling of a community seemed more tangible with the voting and the events. Even though I didn't really care to participate in a lot of events, it was still fun to watch and read about. The sales used to be mark-on-your-calendar and anticipate events and now I barely know when they're occurring.
That wasn't during the "spiritual adventures" being talked about. Plenty of people were close to someone when they departed.
That wasn't during the "spiritual adventures" being talked about. Plenty of people were close to someone when they departed.
SciFi. The pilot was so good, I still think of the missed opportunity often.

Yes, yes...I think everyone gets that seeing a real painting is better than a book. This isn't a difficult concept to grasp. It applies to basically everything in life. We get it. But not everyone can see every painting in the world with their own eyes. They have accepted the fact that a reproduction may be their only option. Or believe it's perfectly fine to enjoy an art book until they get the opportunity to visit the right museums. No one is going too argue that you're wrong and their book was a better experience than seeing the real deal.
Elderberry(bury) tea.

I haven't played it, but it did seem like a near perfect copy of Letters from Whitechapel with a little added complications which didn't seem fitting for the theme at all. I'm fine with sticking with Letters for this type of gameplay and Camp Grizzly for this theme. Anyone who wants a slasher board game should check Camp Grizzly out, it does a great job of capturing the atmosphere worth easy, fun, quick gameplay.

I don't think people with opposing viewpoints should be shot down or treated rudely, by any means, but it doesn't really out you on a good footing when you come in with your first post basically stating a fact that it's objectively a bad show and everyone who has been watching and enjoying for three years must be mentally defective. It couldn't possibly be that the approach and execution is just not personally your style.
Oh. Whoops.
What do you mean? It makes exactly the same sense. They're calling people fragile and easily offended, critics are turning it around and saying republicans are fragile and easily offended.

I've always liked miniature paintings/drawings like those Lorraine Loots and others create, so I thought I'd try to take a stab at doing a mini-burger. I have problems getting shaky when doing detail work and figured this could be a good exercise to try to remedy and calm that tendency. Also good practice at making tiny, tiny lines and shapes with watercolor and see just how small I could get and still keep things defined and clear. I thought about using colored pencils at the end to finish details and textures but I decided to stick to watercolor and push it to see how intricate I could get with paints alone.
And they had made kind of a big deal about it months ago, Elba specifically talking how he approached the voice. And now...this, he sounds like he did in The Office.
"Yeah, but it looks cool, don't it?!" - Sony
At least I have quite a lot of confidence in It. It'll be coming along soon enough to hopefully wash away the bad taste left by the Dark Tower.

Malcolm in the Middle is, incorrectly I would say, placed in California. I think the show pretty consciously avoided being pinned down geographically. The most you could surmise is moments where, like, Francis, took forever to hitchhike to Alaska...and that would be vague and imprecise.
Also Brooklyn Nine Nine is put in California instead of, ya know, Brooklyn...so there's some inaccuracies in there.

Perhaps I've finally found my calling.

The first burgers I did..well, at least one of them, maybe not both...had sesame seeds on the buns but I was too intimidated so I just ignored them. But I decided if I was gonna paint a year's worth of burgers, sesame seeds were gonna be an issue I had to tackle sooner than later. Wasn't nearly as bad as I had feared.
It was uncharted territory for sure, I wasn't confident I'd be able to get the definition I was liking with using ink but this came out pretty well. Thanks!
Thanks very much, I've been pretty happy with how quickly I've picked up on techniques and tricks.

Reminds me of shop class where we were using these little razor choppers, like the heavy duty paper cutters but just with a small razor blade in the arm, to chop lengths of balsa wood. The teacher explained that we just had to be careful and work slowly and we wouldn't get hurt, if we cut ourselves we were idiots. A couple weeks later my partner somehow cut himself and went up to the teacher and said, "I'm an idiot." Best way to break the news.
I didn't imagine, but I didn't want to come off like a clueless, self-centered American.

They can be such s funny, frustrating company sometimes. How much time and effort went into making a blimp system...which as an American is a wacky, bonkers thing, is airship travel common in 21st century Europe?...but something so glaringly obvious and basic as the ridiculous gondolas is overlooked and not a concern.

Another of my monthly cheeseburgers, a couple weeks late. I had serious qualms and frustrations with this one near the middle and couldn't get motivated to work.
For no real reason, I decided to paint a burger each month as a kinda progress report and see how I'm improving and learning. The burger was chosen at random, but it's a pretty good subject to practice and experiment with-multiple types of textures and a variety of colors.
I try to approach each one a little differently, with this one I wanted to break free from the ink outlines I've done with every other painting and just rely on paint. No ink and no white gel pens at the end. That meant this was also the first time I used making fluid.
Cool, thanks very much for the info.

This was a great read. I have a 19 mo. old that I'm aching to be able to play games with. Now I've got some good ideas on some first ones to grab.
Hopefully barring some well-meaning gifts, I won't have to sit through Candy Land and the like and we can keep on the path of good modern board gaming.

The real hook of the game is being able to pay with a lot of people easily since almost everyone has a smart phone and being able to do things like type and draw much quicker than you would on any game controller. There's no advantage in being locked into using the joy cons.
There is still a great advantage to having it on switch though, since it'll be the ultimate portable version of the game and super easy to bring to parties and gatherings where you have the largest number off potential players. It's genius.
How would they not have enough food? People don't suddenly show up mid-flight and throw their meal count off.

It's kinda neat that Damon Lindelof and Carlton Cuse, showrunners that had maybe the most pressure and highest expectations on their ending, are going through this final stretch again at the same time.

Oh I get it, I just think it's an awfully convenient way to go about it for the filmmakers. Toss in enough stuff to bring in book fans but they also don't have to deal with the burden and expectations of being an adaptation and can invent and change whatever they want to. They get to take advantage of a built in fanbase and at the same time almost have the freedom of their own IP.
Just because they are going this route and have this freedom with the narrative doesn't mean criticism is unjustified. They can, and it sounds like they certainly have in some instances, add in stupid ideas that deserved to be called out.

Same here, the lyrics always sounded like someone who was** gone** gone, and not old friends that were gone by time or distance or just drifting apart or whatever the sentiment originally was. Even the "til the school bus came and took my friends away" was acknowledging the accident in a slightly metaphorical way.
